member.name: M:NMoneys.Currency.InitializeAllCurrencies
member.summary: Actively initializes the information for all currencies.
member.remarks:
Use this method if you plan to use a lot of currencies in your program.
When most of currencies are expected to be used, it is recommeneded to initialize the information for all of them, saving time each time the first instance is accessed.

member.name: M:NMoneys.Currency.CompareTo(System.Object)
member.summary: Compares the current instance with another object of the same type and returns an integer that indicates whether the current instance precedes, follows, or occurs in the same position in the sort order as the other object.
member.param: An object to compare with this instance.
member.returns:
A 32-bit signed integer that indicates the relative order of the objects being compared. The return value has these meanings:
Value Meaning
Less than zero This instance is less than .
Zero This instance is equal to .
Greater than zero This instance is greater than .
member.exception: is not a .

Greater than zero This instance is greater than .

member.name: M:NMoneys.Currency.Get(NMoneys.CurrencyIsoCode)
member.summary: Obtains the instance of associated to the specified.
member.remarks:
behaves as a singleton, therefore successive calls to will return the same instance of .
An internal cache with the information of the currency is maintained. If it is the first time such currency is obtained within the context of the running application, the information will be loaded individually.
If many different instances of are to be used, it is recommended the use of in order to save some initialization time.
member.returns: The instance of represented by the .
member.exception: The does not exist in the enumeration.
The currency represented by has not been properly configured by the library implementor. Please, log a issue.

behaves as a singleton, therefore successive calls to will return the same instance of .

member.name: E:NMoneys.Currency.ObsoleteCurrency
member.summary: Occurs when an obsolete currency is created.
member.remarks:
Do remember to unsubscribe from this event when you are no longer insterested it its ocurrence. Failing to do so can prevent your objects from being garbage collected and result in a memory leak.
By its static nature, the notification is available even when no instance of the class is existing yet. This very same nature will cause that subscribers are notified for ocurrences that are "far" from the code that is likely to raise an event in concurrent systems. For example, another thread could make the event to raise and a totally unrelated code will get the notification. This may well be the desired effect, but awareness need to be raised for when it is not the desired effect.
Currencies are transient entities in the real world, getting deprecated and/or substituted. When a currency that is no longer current is created this event will be raised. This can happen in a number of cases:
A factory method is used.
A instance gets deserialized.
A instance gets created.
A instance gets deserialized.

member.name: M:NMoneys.Currency.Code.Parse(System.String)
member.summary: Converts the string representation of the name or numeric value of one or more enumerated constants to an equivalent .
member.remarks:
The can represent an alphabetic or a numeric currency code.

Only defined numeric codes can be parsed.

member.returns: An object of type whose value is represented by value.
member.exception: is null.
does not represent a defined alphabetic or numeric code.

members.member:
Creates an instance with the specified and the from the region associated with the current culture.
The current culture is calculated as the value of .
There might be cases that the framework will provide non-standard or out-dated information for the current culture. In this case it might be possible that an exception is thrown even if the region corresponding to the current culture can be created.
The of the monetary quantity. An instance of with the specified and the currency associated to the current culture. /// The current is either an invariant or custom, or a cannot be instantiated from it. The ISO symbol associated to the current culture does not exist in the enumeration. The currency associated to the current culture has not been properly configured by the library implementor. Please, log a issue.

member.name: M:NMoneys.Money.ForCulture(System.Decimal,System.Globalization.CultureInfo)
member.summary: Creates an instance with the specified and the from the region associated with the provided .
member.remarks: There might be cases that the framework will provided non-standard or out-dated information for the given . In this case it might be possible that an exception is thrown even if the region corresponding to the can be created.
member.param: A from which retrieve the associated currency.
member.returns: An instance of with the specified and the currency associated to the specified .
member.exception: is null.
is either an invariant, custom or neutral culture, or a cannot be instantiated from it.
The ISO symbol associated to the does not exist in the enumeration.
The currency associated to the has not been properly configured by the library implementor. Please, log a issue.

members.member:
Creates an instance of from an amount in major units of the specified currency.
Allows creating an instance with an amount expressed in terms of the minor unit of the currency.
For example, when constructing 'US Dollars', the represents 'cents'.
When the currency has zero decimal places, and are the same.

member.name: M:NMoneys.Money.CompareTo(System.Object)
member.summary: Compares the current instance with another object of the same type and returns an integer that indicates whether the current instance precedes, follows, or occurs in the same position in the sort order as the other object.
member.param: An object to compare with this instance.
member.returns:
A 32-bit signed integer that indicates the relative order of the objects being compared. The return value has these meanings:
Value Meaning
Less than zero This instance is less than .
Zero This instance is equal to .
Greater than zero This instance is greater than .
member.exception: is not a .

member.param: A value that specifies how to round if it is midway between two other numbers.

member.name: M:NMoneys.Money.Round
member.summary: Rounds to a the number of decimal places specified by the identified by .
member.returns: A with the equivalent to previous rounded to the number of decimal places specified by its .
member.remarks:
When is exactly halfway between two rounded values, the resultant is the rounded value that has an even digit in the far right decimal position. For example, when rounded to two s, the value 2.345 becomes 2.34 and the value 2.355 becomes 2.36. This process is known as rounding toward even, or rounding to nearest.
The behavior of this method follows IEEE Standard 754, section 4. This kind of rounding is sometimes called rounding to nearest or banker's rounding.

member.name: M:NMoneys.Money.Round(System.MidpointRounding)
member.summary: Rounds to a precision specified by the identified by . specifies how to round the value if it is midway between two other numbers.
member.param: A value that specifies how to round if it is midway between two other numbers.
member.returns: A with that is nearest to the previous with a precision equal to . If is halfway between two numbers, one of which is even and the other odd, the mode parameter determines which of the two numbers is chosen. If the precision of is less than , remains unchanged.
member.remarks:
The specifies the number of significant decimal places in the return value and ranges from 0 to 28.
If is zero, an integer is returned.
The behavior of this method follows IEEE Standard 754, section 4. This kind of rounding is sometimes called rounding to nearest or banker's rounding.
If is zero, this kind of rounding is sometimes called rounding toward zero.

member.name: M:NMoneys.Money.Round(System.Int32)

member.returns: A with rounded to decimals number of decimal places.
member.remarks: The behavior of this method follows IEEE Standard 754, section 4. This kind of rounding is sometimes called rounding to nearest or banker's rounding.

member.remarks:
The specifies the number of significant decimal places in the return value and ranges from 0 to 28.
If is zero, an integer is returned.
The behavior of this method follows IEEE Standard 754, section 4. This kind of rounding is sometimes called rounding to nearest or banker's rounding.
If is zero, this kind of rounding is sometimes called rounding toward zero.

member.name: P:NMoneys.Money.CurrencyCode
member.summary: The ISO 4217 code of the currency of a monetary quantity.

member.name: P:NMoneys.Money.Amount
member.summary: The amount of a monetary quantity

member.name: P:NMoneys.Money.MajorAmount
member.summary: Gets the amount in major units
member.remarks:
This method returns the monetary amount in terms of the major units of the currency, truncating the if necessary.
For example, 'EUR 2.35' will return a major amount of 2, since EUR has 2 significant decimal values. 'BHD -1.345' will return -1.

member.name: P:NMoneys.Money.MajorIntegralAmount
member.summary: Gets the amount in major units as a .
member.remarks:
This property returns the monetary amount in terms of the major units of the currency, truncating the amount if necessary.
For example, 'EUR 2.35' will return a major amount of 2, since EUR has 2 significant decimal values. 'BHD -1.345' will return -1.

member.name: P:NMoneys.Money.MinorAmount
member.summary: Gets the amount in minor units.
member.remarks:
This property return the monetary amount in terms of the minor units of the currency, truncating the amount if necessary.
For example, 'EUR 2.35' will return a minor amount of 235, since EUR has 2 significant decimal values. 'BHD -1.345' will return -1345.

member.name: P:NMoneys.Money.MinorIntegralAmount
member.summary: Gets the amount in minor units as a .
member.remarks:
This property return the monetary amount in terms of the minor units of the currency, truncating the amount if necessary.
For example, 'EUR 2.35' will return a minor amount of 235, since EUR has 2 significant decimal values. 'BHD -1.345' will return -1345.
